Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2015 10:01PM Trichick1964 wrote: This hardest part of this journey (whether it's ultimately benign or not) is the waiting! It's absolutely torturous. I like your description of a woodpecker picking at your head (I may borrow that if you don't mind). Try your Hardest to find things that distract you or calm you while you wait. Exercise is a great way to burn up some of that excess anxiety and you get the added endorphin benefit. And I agree with everyone else, see if they can put you on a cancellation list so you have the possibility of getting an earlier appointment. I hate to say it, but the one consistency I found in all this breast anxiety is that nothing happens quickly and no matter how long the wait, it's excruciating. You are not alone!
Posts.Title: Terrified!!! Kelsklo98 MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2015 09:37PM Trichick1964 wrote: Hi Joseanna, I'm new here, still waiting on diagnosis, but felt compelled to respond to your post. You're handling so much right now. I'm so sorry for your diagnosis, and also so thankful that the marvels of modern medicine can treat you. Hugs to you !
Posts.Title: 41 and just had a baby waiting for confirmation Prettyblueyes KSkier

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2015 09:47PM Trichick1964 wrote: I had a stereotactic biopsy and literally felt nothing, not even the numbing shot. I was very anxious about having to be in one position for too long because I had had a terrible back flare up a few days before the procedure (landing me in the ER). I did fine though. They had a tough time getting me positioned so that they could get to the cluster because it was so deep, but after 20 minutes of manipulating, squashing, repositioning, pulling, etc., the biopsy went off without a hitch. I literally felt nothing. I did tell them that my right breast was going to be hanging about 2 inches lower than my left after all that, but alas, it sprung back into place nicely... ha! I left wrapped in an Ace bandage with an ice pack tucked in there and never took anything stronger than a Tylenol. I think the hardest part of all of this is the waiting and anticipation. In an odd way, my back flare up and pain from that probably provided me with some much needed distraction from the anxiety of having the procedure (although I wouldn't recommend this approach). I wish you the very best and pray for a good outcome!
